text.title: Who shall go up for us first against the Canaanites:

pasuk.text: To the places for which we cast lots but were not yet conquered.
The tribe of Judah shall go up first to conquer its portion.
i.e., To the tribe of Simeon.

text.title: Come up with me into my lot:

pasuk.text: Come up with me and help me conquer that which fell as my portion. Some interpret “Judah shall go up” referring to Othniel, being Yabetz, of whom we say in Tractate Temura (16a), “Judah, the brother of Simeon, is his name,” and Simeon, his brother, he asked to go with him.
This is the name of the place.

From here you can learn [the extent of] the greatness and wealth of the kings of Canaan [mentioned in Josh. 12:7 24] since Adoni bezek was not even worthy of being counted among the kings of Canaan and [yet] it is so written of him [Sifre Deut. 33: 17].

text.title: And they brought him to Jerusalem:

pasuk.text: They went from there to wage war against Jerusalem.
They set a fire throughout all of it.
From his mother.
Targum Jonathan renders, וְאַמְלַכְתֵּיהּ, an expression of convincing, that you counsel a person and persuade him in a certain way. So it appears to me.
Targum Jonathan renders וְאִתְרְכִינַת, she bent over to fall at her father’s feet.
I.e., A person whose house is arid [devoid] of all earthly good, who has nothing but Torah.
A rain [or, naturally] sustained field, as Targum Jonathan renders אֲתַר בֵּית שַׁקְיָא דְמַיָא [an adequately watered place].

text.title: from the city of date palms:

pasuk.text: That is Jericho. They were given the fat pasture grounds of Jericho to eat until the Temple would be built. The one in whose portion the Temple was to be built would take this [instead], so that all Israel could have a portion in the Temple [i.e., so that the Temple would not be built upon the private property of any particular tribe]. It was given to the children of Jethro for four hundred forty years [until the Temple was built], during which the students among them left it and went to Othniel the son of Kenaz, who is Jabetz, in the desert of Judah, which is in the south of Arad, to study Torah.
With the students who sat before him. He asked of God to provide for him proper students, as it says, [I Chron. 4:10] “And Jabetz called to God, etc.” And He provided for him these pious people.

text.title: but they could not drive out:

pasuk.text: Targum Jonathan paraphrases: But after they had sinned, they were unable to drive out the inhabitants of the plain.

There was a section in Jerusalem called Jebuse, which was populated by the descendants of Abimelech who were not driven out because of the oath [which Abraham had sworn], until the coming of David. This was because his grandson was still alive and Abraham had sworn [Gen. 21:23] to him, his son, and grandson.

Which fell to their lot. Although the idol of Micah was with them, since Micah was from the tribe of Ephraim, it nevertheless states here, “the Lord was with them.” That is what Daniel said, [Daniel 9: 7] “To You, Lord, there is charity, and to us there is shame of face.”

Through others, as Targum Jonathan renders וּשְׁלַחוּ מְאַלְלִין [and they sent spies]. [Num. 13:21] וַיָּתֻרוּ, “And they spied the land,” is said of the spies themselves, and of those that sent spies it is said, וַיַּתִּירוּ [“caused to spy”].
They entered the city through a cave over which one hazelnut bush (לוּז) stood at the entrance and one would enter through the bush into the cave.
Upon which small nuts grow. Courdre [in Old French a hazelnut bush].
[By pointing] with his finger.

text.title: this is its name until this day:

pasuk.text: Sannacherib did not repatriate it, nor did Nebuchadnezzar destroy it.

text.title: And Menasseh did not drive out:

pasuk.text: The Scripture tells of their shame; they began to betray the Holy One, blessed be He, Who commanded them, [Num. 33:52] “You shall drive out all the inhabitants of the land, etc.”

text.title: And a messenger of the Lord went up:

pasuk.text: We learned in Seder Olam that this was Phinehas.
This is the name of the place (see below v.5).
So I intended initially to take you out of Egypt and so I did, on the condition that you drive out my enemies.
Now I said in my anger.
As pokers in your sides with troops and marauders to plunder and spoil.

text.title: And Joshua had sent away, etc.:

pasuk.text: This incident actually occurred earlier, but since the Scripture is coming to tell us (v.11) “And they did that which is evil,” it begins with the following: Before Joshua died and they (Israel) accepted before him to serve God, he sent them each to his inheritance, and they served God all his (Joshua’s) days and the days of the elders, etc., and afterwards, “And the children of Israel did evil, etc.”

Heb. הֶאֱרִיכוּ. Lit., their days were lengthened but their years were not, because they were lax with his eulogy. And so it says (v.9) “Mount גָּעַש,” the mountain quaked (געש) over them to kill them (Sab. 105b).
It was called so because they erected a picture (תְּמוּנָה) of the sun (חֶרֶס) on his grave as though to say: How unfortunate, the person who stopped the sun (Josh. 10:12) lies in a grave.

text.title: Wherever they went out, the hand of the Lord was against them for evil:

pasuk.text: Concerning Elimelech, Machlon, and Kilyon it was said. In Seder Olam 12.

text.title: And the Lord raised up judges:

pasuk.text: Constantly in each generation, as they are enumerated in this book, judge after judge.
This is in the present tense: And when He raised for them judges, God would be with the judge, etc.
He would retract from the evil. So renders Targum Jonathan .
Because of their cry that arose before Him because of their enemies.
They did not leave over anything for which reason they were reproached through all that befell them.
The “heh” (of הֲשׁוֹמְרִים is vocalized הֲ because it is an expression of question and testing (i.e., would they keep, etc.).
(To test) the other generation that did not know about the miracles of the battles with Canaan and did not witness the great act and (therefore) rebelled against the Omnipresent.
Just for this alone did He allow them to remain, to explain to future generations of the children of Israel what sin causes, for now they are required to study warfare.
Who stood in the service of God.
These battles and their tactics, and they did not need them.

text.title: The five lords of the Philistines:

pasuk.text: These were the nations that He left to test (them).

text.title: And the spirit of the Lord came upon him:

pasuk.text: Rabbi Tanchuma expounded: He contemplated what the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses in Egypt, (Ex. 3:7) “I have surely seen (רָאֹה רָאִיתִי) the oppression of my people.” What are these two expressions of seeing? The Almighty said to him, “I have seen that they are destined to go astray by (worshipping) the calf, but nevertheless I have seen the oppression of My people (in Egypt and I will therefore save them).” Thus said Othniel, whether innocent or guilty He must save them.

text.title: the city of the date palms:

pasuk.text: Jericho.

Targum Jonathan renders, “a person with a shriveled (גְמִיד) right hand.” Any (word) גְמִיד is an Aramaic expression (meaning) something shriveled by disease. Retrait in O.F. (shortened. Likewise אִטֵּר is found in Sab. 103a.) He had no use of his right hand. In Hebrew (the word) אִטֵּר means “closed” as in, (Psalms 69:16) “Do not close upon me, O well, your mouth.” His right hand was closed up and he had no use of it.
A short cubit. In German daumen lang , in 0.F. espan courte.
Because he controlled his left hand, he would grasp it with his left hand (from his right thigh).
Fat.
He went back to escort the group of Israelites that had come with him to bring the tribute and he escorted them up to Gilgal.
Alone.

(Heb. פְּסִילִים) The place where they quarry (Heb. פּוֹסְלִים) stones from the mountain. And so does Targum Jonathan render (מִן מַחֲצָבַיָא) “from the quarries.” Then he came to Eglon and said to him…
Eglon said, “Silence everyone from me.” Targum Jonathan renders הָס as (סְלִיק) remove, i.e., remove everyone, (but) nevertheless הַס is a term of silencing.
In his summer attic which was ventilated and cool.

text.title: I have a message from God to you:

pasuk.text: And you must rise.

text.title: And he stood up from the chair:

pasuk.text: Therefore he merited that Ruth was descended from him.
This is the metal into which the blade is inserted, which is called hulot in 0.F. (a handle). This holds the sword over the sheath.
This is the blade which is called brant in O.F. and lama in O.F.
His fat, for he was very fat, and it covered the whole length of the sword.

Targum Jonathan renders (וּנְפַק אוּכְלֵיה שְׁפִי) “and the excrement spilled out.” He interprets it as two words with the “shin” serving both וַיֵּצֵא הַפַּרְשׁ שְׁדוֹנָה“spilled out.” שָׁפָ is rendered שדא (see Lev. 17:4, 13).

text.title: And Ehud went out to the porch:

pasuk.text: From the attic to the מִסְדְּרוֹנָה which Jonathan renders “to a porch”.
With a key.

text.title: Now when he had gone out (his servants came):

pasuk.text: Ehud went out and the servants of Eglon entered.
Targum Jonathan renders עָבִיד צוֹרְכֵיה (doing his needs), i. e., moving his bowels (based on Yeb. 103a).
Until they were detained, meaning a long time.
Escaped, eschamocrier in O.F.
(עַד) As in, (Song of Songs 1:12) “ While (עַד) the King was still feasting,” (ibid 2:7) “the love while (עַד) we still desire,” i.e., while we both still desire it.

To a fine thick forest called brousaille in O.F. (“brush”) which is good for hiding. This word occurs often in the Order of Zeraim that fine branches of trees are called שֵׂעָר as in (Kilayim 4:9) “He turned the branches (שֵׂעָר) ,” (Peah 2:3) “If the branches (שער) adjoined”.

text.title: And it was when he came:

pasuk.text: He crossed the Jordan and came to his place in the land of Canaan.

Which was in the land of Canaan on the western side of the Jordan, whereas the land of Moab was on the eastern side, and since they ruled over Israel, they had crossed the Jordan and conquered Jericho, as it is written above (v. 13), and they had placed their lords and rulers over Israel.
To kill the Moabites who are on our side of the Jordan.

text.title: and seized the fords of the Jordan:

pasuk.text: Lest the Moabites cross to flee and return to their land.
(Targum Jonathan renders שָׁמֵן as) “Every awesome man.”
This is the metal of an ox goad, aiguillon in 0ld French.
The city was so named because it was powerful and occupied a dominant position.

text.title: oppressed the children of Israel mightily:

pasuk.text: Heb. בְּחָזְקָה. Rabbi Tanchuma (Behar) expounded: With insults, and so it says, (Mal. 3:13) “Your words are unbearable (חָזְקוּ).”
She prepared wicks for the Sanctuary.
She had palm trees in Jericho.

text.title: between Ramah and Beth-el, in the mountain of Ephraim:

pasuk.text: According to Targum Jonathan’s rendering, we can derive that this verse is not to be taken literally. These were not her places of lodging but rather she was a wealthy woman and from these places she earned a livelihood and dwelt in her city Ataroth. Hence:

She had palm trees in Jericho, vineyards in Ramah, olives in the plain of Beth-el where oil was abundant, and (עָפָר חִיוֵר) white earth in the mountain of Ephraim in Tur Malka. I say that this was sold to potters. Some interpret עפר חיור - A sown field like a grain field.
Through Moses (Deut. 20:17), “You shall totally destroy them.” So it is stated in the Mechilta.
(An expression meaning) with him.

Targum Jonathan renders מֵישָׁר אַגְנַיָא the site of a plain (אֵלוֹן) of pits (בְּצָעִים), mariscusm in 0.F. This (i.e., בְּצָעִים) means אַגְנַיָא, being cavities similar to pits where water gathers, as in (Kiddushin 61a) “They are called pits (אגני) of the ground.”

text.title: from Harosheth-goiim, to the brook Kishon:

pasuk.text: He gathered them to go to the brook Kishon from Harosheth-goiim where he dwelt.
Targum Jonathan renders בְּגוּנְכָא which Rav Hai Gaon explains: a garment. Coate in O.F.
She gave him milk because it slackens the body and causes drowsiness.

text.title: Stand in the doorway of the tent:

pasuk.text: (עֲמֹד) is masc.) Hasten like a man. And some interpret עֲמֹד as (לַעֲמוֹד) “to stand”.

Chevilles in 0.F. A peg which is inserted into the ground together with the lower portion of a tent to stretch it out. הַמַּקֶּבֶת, Targum Jonathan renders ארזפתא, martel in Old French (a hammer). בַּלָּאט Targum Jonathan renders בְּרָז i.e., stealthily. וַתִּצְנַח בָּאָרֶץ Targum Jonathan renders וּנְעָצַת בְאַרְעָא : and it pierced through into the ground.
Targum Jonathan renders בְצִידְעֵיה (in his temple) tenplia in O.F. She had thrust it through his temple into the ground.

text.title: When breaches are made in Israel, when the people offer themselves willingly:

pasuk.text: When breaches come upon Israel, for their enemies made breaches in them because they forsook their God and the masses feel motivated to repent, as of now it is proper to bless God (out of thankfulness) for the salvation He has wrought.

This word is repeated. I have heard an Aggadic interpretation: The Holy One did not rob (by withholding) the reward of Mount Tabor and Mount Carmel who arrived at the giving of the Torah, expecting it to be given upon them, and turned away in shame. The Holy One said to them, “I will pay you double fold. It was said at Sinai, (Ex. 20:2) ‘(אָנֹכִי) I am the Lord your God,’ at Tabor it will be said, ‘I… I…’ (אָנֹכִי אָנֹכִי). It was said at Sinai, ‘I am the Lord your God (ה׳ אֱלֹקֶי),’ at Carmel it will be said twice, (I Kings 18:39) ‘The Lord He is God, the Lord He is God (ה׳ הוּא הָאֱלֹקִים)’ in the days of Elijah.”

text.title: Lord, when You went forth out of Seir:

pasuk.text: This refers to the giving of the Torah as it says, “And He appeared to them from Seir” (Deut. 33:2). The relation here is that thus said Deborah: “The Torah is detrimental to forsake and rewarding to cling to it for amidst awe and might it was given. Therefore Israel was delivered into the hands of their adversaries because they forsook it, but when they decided to engage in it they were saved.” This can be derived from Targum Jonathan’s translation. נָטְפוּ - Dripped a life sustaining dew.
(Heb. נָזְלוּ) Like flowing water (נוֹזְלִים) they melted away.
It is already stated what appeared there. (See Ex. 19:16 19, 20:15.) It was completely in smoke and amidst thunder, torches, and fire.

text.title: because of the presence of the Lord:

pasuk.text: This is an abbreviated verse: This was at Sinai; that which occurred there was because God descended upon it.

text.title: In the days of Shamgar the son of Anath, in the days of Jael:

pasuk.text: (Since they are equated,) This teaches us that Jael also judged Israel in her days.
Israel was afraid to travel because of the enemy, hence they followed winding roads in secrecy.
Heb. פְרָזוֹן. Open cities (פְּרָזִי), without walls, ceased to be inhabited because of the enemies, and they gathered into the fortified cities.
Heb. שַׁקַּמְתִּי. Interpreted as שֶׁקַּמְתִּי as below (6:17) “שָׁאַתָּה מְדַבֵּר עִמִּי” (That you are speaking with me, understood as שֶׁאַתָּה.)

text.title: When they chose new gods then there was war in the cities:

pasuk.text: When Israel chose new gods (cf. Deut. 32:17), they were then subject to war within their cities. However, look now when they were willing, will there be seen among Israel a shield or a spear to use in battle against the 40,000 generals the heathens brought upon them. The Almighty confused all of them in the battle with the stars, and the brook of Kishon raked them away.
(שְׁעָרִים is usually interpreted as gates, however, here it means cities,) as in (Deut. 17:2), “When it will be found among you, within one of your cities” (שְׁעָרֶי).
I, Deborah, (my heart) is out to the lawgivers of Israel; to love the wise men of Israel who volunteered to tell the people, “Bless the Lord and return to Him.”

The merchants and nobles who may now ride on the precious white donkeys without fear or worry of the heathens, and those that sit in judgment (מִדִּין is an expression of דַיָּינִים, judges), who were afraid to practice justice publicly, and those that travel on foot, recite and tell of this salvation; (v. 11) that instead of the noise of your adversaries, the ambushers, bandits, and tax collectors who banded together to ambush at the water crossings, there the donkey riders and wayfarers will recite the righteous deeds of the Lord. What are His righteous deeds? Deeds of restoring open cities for Israel, for He granted tranquility to Israel to dwell in open cities and go about scattered, singly, without massing together as a group. Then… went down to the cities They now returned to their home cities whence they had fled to gather in the fortified cities.

Heb. מְחַצְצִים. Menachem (ben Seruk, a Hebrew Grammarian,) interprets, “those that wage war and array battles,” therefore he classifies this along with, (Prov. 30:27) “The locusts have no king, yet they march (חֹצֵץ) together;” an expression of “troops”. Another interpretation is מַשְׁאַבִּים מִקּוֹל מְחַצְצִים בֵּין, When you went to the river to draw water, you feared the sound of the pebbles smoothened by the river, Kiesels in German (cailloux in French is of Celtic origin), for their sound is heard when one passes over them, and you feared being detected by the heathens. However, now you do not have to worry about this. Therefore, it is incumbent upon you to give thanks to His name. מְחַצְצִים (is then) an expression of “pebbles smoothened by the river,” as in (Lam. 3:16) “and he broke with the stones (בֶחָצָץ) my teeth.”

(עוּרִי is) An expression of praise, as in its plain meaning: Become firm in your praise. But our Rabbis said, because she praised herself by saying (v. 7) “Until I Deborah arose,” the Divine spirit left her (therefore she had to arouse (עוֹרֵר) it).

text.title: Then ruled a remnant among the mighty:

pasuk.text: יְרַד = ירדה meaning “ruled,” as in (Isaiah 45:1) “Who rules (לְרַד) nations before Him.” The remnants of Israel ruled over the mighty (אַדִּירֵי) gentiles.

text.title: the Lord dominated the strong for me:

pasuk.text: He gave me dominion (יְרַד לִי) over the mighty of the gentiles.

From Ephraim issued the root (שׁוֹרֶשׁ, referring to Joshua the son of Nun (their prince), to subdue Amalek and weaken him by the sword (Ex. 17:13). This verse is connected to the previous one and explains: The Lord dominated the strong for me by establishing Joshua to subdue Amalek.

Will arise from the tribe of Benjamin, Saul the son of Kish who will stone him and slacken (עֲמָם) him like dying (עוֹמְמוֹת) embers. We can (also) interpret בַּעֲמָמֶי referring to the army of 200,000 soldiers with which Saul came upon them (I Sam. 15:4).

text.title: Out of Machir came down officers:

pasuk.text: Outstanding officers who conquered the Amorites. This refers to those who captured sixty cities, the whole royal stretch conquered under Jair (of Menasseh See Deut. 3: 4, 14).
The princes of Issachar are the Sanhedrin who were occupied in Torah and “knew how to treat the times” (I Chron. 12:32). They are always (cooperating) with Deborah to teach Israel statutes and laws.
Heb. שָׂרַי. The “yud” is inconsequential and does not serve any purpose, as the “yud” in (Ps. 8:8) “the cattle of the field (שָׂדַי)” ; (Jer. 22: 14) “Expand the windows (חַלּוֹנָי).”
(The princes) And the rest of the people of Issachar are faithful to Barak in all that he will instruct.

text.title: into the valley they rushed forth with their feet:

pasuk.text: He sent them for all his errands; to gather the people and for all the needs of war.

But in the divisions of Reuben’s heart were vast חִקְקֵי לֵב, (which Targum Jonathan renders) נִכְלֵי לִיבָּא i.e., shrewdness. And what was his shrewdness? He dwelt by the edges (מִשִׂפְתֵי) of the battle to hear who would win so that he should join with him.
To hear the sound of the flocks in battle; to whom is the sound of victory and to whom is the sound of defeat.
And he did not come to the battle, and likewise Dan gathered his wealth into ships to be prepared to escape.
To watch the vulnerable parts of his land.

text.title: Zebulun is a people that jeopardized…:

pasuk.text: He scorned himself and submitted himself to die in battle with Barak, and likewise Naphtali on the high places of the field, on Mount Tabor.

text.title: in Taanach by the waters of Megiddo:

pasuk.text: Jonathan renders: In Taanach they dwelt and reached until the waters of Megiddo. The edge of the camp was in Taanach and it reached until the waters of Megiddo.

text.title: they took no gain of money:

pasuk.text: Without payment they came to aid Sisera, they asked no reward.
(As they sought no gain,) likewise the Holy One sent against them His hosts who do not desire any reward.

The tip of the star being in heaven and its edge upon earth (see following verses). From here it was said: The thickness of the firmament is equivalent to the space between heaven and earth, since the star is inserted in the firmament like a bolt into a door (this refers to an old fashioned bolt which went through the thickness of the door), i.e., the size of its length equaling the thickness of the firmament. Thus from this verse, which attests that from their courses they fought, we derive that the thickness of the firmament is equal to the height between heaven and earth.
Heb. גְּרָפָם. It swept them from the world like a rake (מַגְרֵפָה) that rakes ashes from an oven.
It became a guarantor to the sea concerning this from the days of Egypt as it is stated in Pesachim (118b).
By using my feet upon the strength (עוֹז) of the mighty of Canaan.

text.title: were pounded the heels of the horses:

pasuk.text: The hoofs of their horses slipped off because the heat of the star would boil the mud and the nail would slip off, as one scalds the feet in boiling water and the hoofs would slip off. And since they slipped off, the feet were stricken (הָלְמוּ) (Mechilta Ex. 14:24).

text.title: by reason of the prancings, the prancings of their mighty ones:

pasuk.text: They would cause their horses to prance in war as in (Nachum 3:2) “And a horse prancing” (דוֹהֵר). This is an expression of the prancing of a horse.
Some say it was a star and some say he was a prominent person who was near the battle area and yet did not come.

text.title: said the messenger of the Lord:

pasuk.text: Said Barak as an agent of the Holy One.
Those that dwell within his four cubits. With (the blast of) four hundred horns, Barak excommunicated Meroz.

text.title: to the aid of the Lord:

pasuk.text: Speaking as though it could be done, for he who aids Israel is as if he is aiding the Divine Presence.

Heb. אֹהֶל. Referring to Sarah of whom it is said, (Gen. 18:9) “She is in the tent,” Rebecca of whom it is said, (ibid. 24:67) “And Isaac brought her into the tent,” and Rachel and Leah of whom it is said, (ibid 31:33) “And he went out of Leah’s tent and he entered Rachel’s tent”.

text.title: above women in the tent shall she be blessed:

pasuk.text: (Referring to) Jael, because they bore and raised children, but if not Jael, this evil one (i.e., Sisera) would have come and destroyed them. So it states in Genesis Rabbah 48. Another interpretation is that Jael also dwelt in tents (above 4:18), therefore she was mentioned in the blessing of tents.
To test his state of consciousness, if he could discern between the taste of water and the taste of milk. So does Targum Jonathan paraphrase.
Heb. אַדִּירִים. In a vessel that one drinks water, since water is called “mighty” (or lordly i. e., אַדִּירִים), as it says, (Ex. 15:10) “In the mighty (אַדִּירִים) waters”.
Heb. עֲמֵלִים. Referring to Sisera who was exhausted (עָמֵל) and tired.
Heb. מָחֲקָה. An expression of piercing (חִיקוּי).
Heb. מָחֲצָה. An expression of wounding (מַחַץ).
Heb. חָלְפָה means “she made pass through” referring to the pin which pierced his head) coming out on the other side.

Heb. וַתְּיַבֵּב. An expression of speaking, as in (Isa. 57:19) “The speech (נִיב) of the lips.” But our Rabbis explained (Rosh Hashanah 33b) מְיַבֵּב as an expression of wailing, as in (Num. 29:1), “Of wailing” (תְּרוּעָה) which is rendered יַבָּבָא. However, I say it is an expression of looking, as in, (Zach. 2:12) “The pupil (בָבַת) of his eye,” and so has Menachem classified it. הָאֶשְׁנָב, the window.

text.title: The wisest of her princesses answer her:

pasuk.text: Heb. חַכְמוֹת is interpreted as “the wise of her princesses” (an adjective in the constructive form), therefore the “Heth” is vocalized with a “patach” (“ah” sounding vowel). חָכְמוֹת as a noun is vocalized “hatof kamatz” (an “aw” sound), as in (Prov. 24:7) “Wisdom (חָכְמוֹת) to a fool is like a rare jewel.” However, this form is vocalized חַכְמוֹת and similarly, (Prov. 14:1) “The wise (חַכְמוֹת) of the women establish their house.”

The dot in the (second) “nun” replaces the third “nun” (which would be needed to replace the word “her”). It thus means “they answer her.” The dot of a “nun” replaces the word “her” as in (Lev. 6:14) “Scalded he shall bring it,” (lit., her) (תְּבִיאֶנָּה).
(Of) Consolation to herself saying: Why am I wondering about my son’s delay? (Are they not, etc.)

text.title: Are they not finding (and) dividing the spoils?:

pasuk.text: And that is delaying them.
They are ravishing the pretty women of Israel and every one of the men has two or three women in his bed.
Deborah said, “This is for her a vain consolation, for so may perish all your enemies, O Lord, as he was destroyed.”

text.title: but they that love Him (should be) as the sun when he goes forth in his might:

pasuk.text: Which will occur in the coming future seven times seven the light of all the seven days of creation which is 343 times as much (as one day). This equals the sum of forty nine times seven. [Tanchuma].
These are not Deborah’s words, but rather the words of the writer of this book.

Until now it was said (above 3: 12, 4:1), “and they continued to do,” because (one) sin was piled on (another) sin, but with this song (ch. 5) they were forgiven for all they had done and it was as though now they were beginning to sin. So it is explained in Aggadath Tehillim .

Hiding places (Targum Jonathan), voutes in Old French, and since a small window (מָאוֹר) is placed in an unnoticeable spot they are called מִנְהָרוֹת (as in Job 3:3 נְהָרָה, meaning “light” [Metzudas Zion]), lucerno in French. מְעָרוֹת. (Caves) grotte in French. מְצָדוֹת is palliser in O.F. (strongholds) because (?) they are made in the forest by chopping down trees from all around.
(Came) to pasture on the grain.
This prophet was Phinehas [Seder Olam 20].
From the family of Abiezer, of the family of Gilead, of the family of Menasseh.

His father was beating them out (i.e., the wheat), and he was sifting them. He then said, “Father, you are old, and if the heathens come, you will not be able to flee. Therefore you go and I will beat them out.”
(he beat the wheat) with the beams of an olivepress (בֵּית הַבַּד).

text.title: The Lord is with you, mighty man of valor:

pasuk.text: Since he has granted you such strength.

text.title: if the Lord be with us:

pasuk.text: (… וְיֵשׁ is to be interpreted as) If God is with us, why has… befallen us?

It was Passover so he said, “Last night my father recited the Hallel and I heard him say, ‘When Israel departed from Egypt, etc.,’ (thus recounting the miracles God performed on behalf of Israel,) but now He has forsaken us. If our forefathers were righteous, let Him perform (wonders) for us in their merit, and if they were wicked, then just as He did for them undeserving wonders, so should He do for us. Where then are all His wonders?”

text.title: And the Lord turned toward him:

pasuk.text: (Not the angel, but) the Holy One, Blessed be He, Himself.
With the strength of this merit that you advocated defense for my children. So did Rabbi Tanchuma (Shoftim) explain (this passage).
Heb. אַלְפִּי. The thousand (אֶלֶף) among whom I am counted to be under a head of a thousand is the lowliest (thousand) among all the thousands of Menasseh.
Interpreted as if vocalized שֶׁאַתָּה, with a “segol” (“eh” sound).

text.title: unleavened cakes of an ephah of meal:

pasuk.text: We see that it was Passover, the day of the waving of the Omer, therefore it was said, (below 7: 13) “And behold, a roasted cake of barley bread tumbled, etc.” וְהַמָּרָק. The broth.
אֲהָהּ is an expression of “worry” meaning, “What will become (תְּהֵא) of me.”
(עַל כֵּן is interpreted as עַל אֲשֶׁר) Because I have seen an angel of the Lord, therefore I worry and cry “Alas.”
I.e., Gideon called the altar.
The Lord is He Who bestows upon us peace.
A young bull (פַּר), because a one day old ox (שוֹר) is (also) called an ox. וּפַר הַשֵּׁנִי And the second bullock.

That was fattened seven years for the idols. Eight transgressions were permitted that night. Gideon offered that which was set aside to be sacrificed for idolatry, he used idolatrous utensils, the offering was at night, it was on a private altar and not in the Sanctuary, he was not a priest, sacred vessels were not used, wood from an Asherah was employed, and an animal that was worshipped was used, as is stated in Temurah 28b.
On top of the rock.

לַבַּעַל ? [The prefix “lamed” does not mean “to” but] for the Baal. אוֹתו ֹתּוֹשִׁיעוּן. Will you avenge him? Similarly, (I Sam. 25:33) “And from avenging (וְהשׁעַ) myself with my own hand,” which David said concerning Nabal.
לוֹ For him.
Tarry until morning.
Let him contend and avenge himself: He said this in order to delay them until Gideon escaped.

i.e., with Gideon. Near (the word) רִיב, the word עִם or אֶת or בּוֹ is used as in, (Gen. 31:36) “And he quarreled with Laban”, but לוֹ cannot be used with this expression. Hence, every לוֹ written here means “for (him)”.

text.title: And a spirit of the Lord:

pasuk.text: A spirit of might.
I.e., the entire family.

There was only dew on the fleece, more so than on other places, as it says, “A bowl full of water.” However, “Upon all the ground it be dry” was not fulfilled because a covenant was made with the dew that it should not cease. וַיָּזַר An expression of “pressed,” and similarly, (Isa. 1:6) “They were neither pressed (זוֹרוּ) nor bandaged,” i.e., they were not pressed to extract the pus.

text.title: By Gibeath moreh, in the valley:

pasuk.text: (מִגִּבְעַת הַמּוֹרָה בָּעֵמֶק.) by the mountain that overlooks the plain (Targum Jonathan). הַמּוֹרָה is an expression of instructing and looking (וּרְאִיָּה הוֹרָאָה, as in (Prov. 6:13) “Instructing (מוֹרֶה) with his fingers,” because from there, one could see and signal into the valley.
vanter in French (i.e., praise themselves)
Heb. וְיִצְפֹּר. I.e., in the morning, as in the Aramaic term צַפְרָא (morning).

text.title: “Every one who laps with his tongue, etc., and (likewise) every one that kneels upon his knees to drink.”:

pasuk.text: Set him (i.e., he who kneels) separately away from your group because they will not go with you since they are thus accustomed to kneel before idols.

text.title: of those that lapped, putting their hand…:

pasuk.text: This is not a kneeling procedure just as one who laps with his tongue (is not considered kneeling).
I.e., they were encamped in the valley.
This is written צְלִול (i.e., empty), because the generation was empty of righteous people. צְלִיל לֶחֶם שׂעוֹרִים A roasted barley bread (Targum Jonathan). A cake baked (צְלִי) on coals.
Symbolizing the merit of the Omer sacrificed on Passover.

text.title: and smote it, and it fell:

pasuk.text: i.e., The tent.
i.e., The tent was completely overturned, and fell.
Heb. מִסְפַּר). The story (סִפּוּר) of the dream, (as Targum Jonathan renders) יַת שוּעִית חֶלְמָא וְיַת פִּשְׁרֵיהּ (the telling of the dream and its interpretation).
Its exchange; meaning, its interpretation (which takes the place of the dream).

To commemorate the merit of the giving of the Torah. However, the simple meaning is that since it was night, as it states (v. 9), it was dark, therefore they took the torches to provide light, and placed them into pitchers lest the torches be discerned.
At what I do, and do likewise.

text.title: I and all that are with me:

pasuk.text: One of the companies consisting of one hundred men was with him.

text.title: For the Lord and for Gideon:

pasuk.text: (Targum Jonathan paraphrases:) The sword that kills is prompted by the Lord, and the victory is through Gideon.

I.e., The soldiers previously (had but recently awakened) the guards, who were to guard during the middle watch; for so it is customary for soldiers to set up watchmen, these would watch for the first third of the night, these for the second third, and these for the last third.

text.title: and they smashed the pitchers that were in their hands:

pasuk.text: (and he told them) to break the pitchers which were in their hands.
A blast to disencamp and flee.

text.title: and seize before them the waters:

pasuk.text: Which separate between Edom and Canaan (Text per Rabbi Joseph Karo).
For it also separated.

text.title: they brought to Gideon beyond the Jordan:

pasuk.text: In the morning, when Gideon crossed the Jordan in pursuit of Zebah and Zalmunna.

text.title: What have I done now in comparison with you?:

pasuk.text: Of what importance is what I did at first, compared with what you subsequently did.

Are not the gleanings that came to your hand at the end better than the vintage that I and my family picked in the beginning, considering that in your hands the Lord delivered the kings (i. e., the princes).
to do that would be as outstanding as your deed?

text.title: he crossed, and the three hundred men:

pasuk.text: They were crossing the Jordan after Zebah and Zalmunna who had passed earlier (perhaps even prior to the blockade above 7:24) and laid waste to the land of Reuben, Gad and Menasseh. Therefore, he crossed to take revenge against them also.
Who were Israelites.

text.title: Is the palm of Zebah and Zalmunna now in your hand:

pasuk.text: That you boast that you saved us from Midian?
Ronzes in O.F.
The name of a place.

text.title: by the way of the tent dwellers:

pasuk.text: Through the land of Kedar and Arabia, whose people live in the desert in tents, constantly grazing their flock and not residing in houses.

text.title: on the east of Nobah and Jogbehah:

pasuk.text: Which were Israelite cities. However, he only wanted to go there roundabout, so that they should not be detected, and thereby suddenly surprise them.

text.title: when the sun was still high:

pasuk.text: I.e., when the sun had not yet set, while the sun (חֶרֶס) still appears high (לְמַעֲלָה).
And broke with them.

text.title: One was as the form of the children of the king:

pasuk.text: Heb. אֶחָד כְּתֹאַר בְּנֵי הַמֶּלֶ. Targum Jonathan renders: One among them appeared like the children of the king. However, we can interpret: As you are, so were they, all of you possessing one appearance (כּמוֹ כְמוֹהֶם אֶחָד); since they appeared like the children of kings (כְּתֹאַר בְּנֵי הַמֶּלֶ).

text.title: But the young man did not draw his sword:

pasuk.text: To kill them, because he was afraid of them.
Of gold, lunettes in O.F.
The crescents and the pendants [after Targum Jonathan].

text.title: And Gideon made it into an Ephod:

pasuk.text: To serve as a reminder of the great victory, by showing how immense their army was that the nose rings of the nobles amounted to all this gold.

text.title: and all Israel went astray after it:

pasuk.text: After Gideon’s death.
This was its name.
Lit. in four heads.

text.title: And they did not do kindness with the house of Jerubbaal:

pasuk.text: They killed his sons, as Scripture states below (9: 5).
פוֹחֲזִים. Hasty in their actions, to do without meditation.

text.title: by the plain of the stones:

pasuk.text: Heb. אֵלוֹן מֻצָּב. Targum Jonathan renders מֵישַׁר קָמָתָא, i.e., a plain (אֵלוֹן) containing monuments (מַצֵּבוֹת).
This is allegorical.

Referring to Othniel the son of Kenaz from the tribe of Judah, which is called an olive tree, as it says, (Jer. 11:16) “Like a fresh olive tree, beautiful in form, etc.” (this refers to the cities of Judah mentioned in v. 13 ibid).
This is an expression of “fatness.”
Deborah.
(Referring to) the bee’s honey.
Referring to Gideon who descended from Joseph of whom it is said, (Gen. 49:22) “A fruitful son is Joseph; blessed as a vine standing by the water” (as per Onkelos).
For the Levites do not recite the sacrificial song of praise but during the libations of wine.
Heb. הָאָטָד, epine in O.F.
I.e., because I am fit to rule.
Forcefully and arrogantly he held his position.
A spirit of hatred, (טלנט), talent in O.F.
He was from another nation.
And they made dances [quoting Targum Jonathan].

text.title: Who is Abimelech and who is Shechem:

pasuk.text: Who is Abimelech that he should rule over Shechem, and who is Shechem to be servants to Abimelech? Was not Abimelech the son of Jerubbaal (הֲלֹא בֶן יַרֻבַּעַל) from Ophrah of the Abiezrites?

text.title: and Zebul (is he not) his officer:

pasuk.text: As for the officer of the city whose name is Zebul, he is (but) an officer of Abimelech; since his master has no right to rule here, neither do his appointees.
If you are coming to acquire for yourselves leaders, come and serve the men of Hamor, who was a previous lord over the land.

text.title: but why should we serve him:

pasuk.text: I.e., Abimelech.
(Indirectly;) and Gaal spoke before Zebul to inform Abimelech (as subsequently evident).

text.title: Increase your army, and come out:

pasuk.text: From the place where you are, and let us see your greatness.
Heb. בְּתָרְמָה. As in (Gen. 27:35) “בְּמִרְמָה,” and (Jer. 8: 5) “בּתַרְמִית,” i.e., quietly and secretly.

text.title: from the navel of the earth:

pasuk.text: (Targum Jonathan renders) מִן תּוּקְפָא דְאַרְעָא (i. e., from the strength of the land) from its highest mountain. Combine 2 Heb. words אֵלוֹן מְעוֹנְנִים, the plain of Meonenim.

text.title: that the people went out to the field:

pasuk.text: The people of Shechem.
The informers told Abimelech that the citizens went out to the field to attend their needs.

text.title: in the entrance of the gate of the city:

pasuk.text: So that no one could enter.
צְרִיחַ in Heb. A forest in which the trees and branches are bent over all around the forest; plissé in O. F.
That forest belonged to Baal Brith (above v. 4), the name of their idol. Zalmon (v. 48) also had a forest. Some interpret צְרִיחַ as voutes in O.F., which is made in the ground.
A bough from a tree.
A piece of the upper millstone which is called a רֶכֶב.
וְתָרִץ same as וּתְרוֹצֵץ (a more familiar form).
Lit. lest they say to me.
Heb. דוֹדוֹ, this was his name.
(Targum Jonathan renders) עוּלִין, i.e., colts.
And they had thirty unwalled cities. It therefore states עֲיָרִים which is an expression of unwalled cities (עֲיָירוֹת).
Seven idols are enumerated here.

text.title: and they forsook the Lord, and did not serve Him:

pasuk.text: Even in conjunction with the idols.
When Jair died.

text.title: (the children of Israel) that were beyond the Jordan:

pasuk.text: I.e., The land of Reuben, Gad, and half of Menasseh who were their neighbors.

text.title: Did (I) not (save you) from the Egyptians:

pasuk.text: Seven deliverances are mentioned here, corresponding to the seven heathen gods that they served.
This is the name of a nation.

text.title: and His soul was grieved by the toil:

pasuk.text: As if one could say, He did not have the expanse to endure and contain the anguish caused Him by the toil (or suffering) Of Israel.
Heb. וַיִּצְּעֲקוּ. They gathered through announcements.

text.title: and the children of Ammon made war:

pasuk.text: (The war) referred to above.
The stipulation which was between them.
At the place where they all gathered (above 10:17), since the Divine Presence resides amongst the multitudes of the congregation.
Located south of the land of Edom which is itself located to the south of the land of Canaan.

text.title: Let me pass now through your land:

pasuk.text: From the South to the North to enter the land of Canaan.

text.title: and also to the king of Moab:

pasuk.text: Whose land was adjacent to the land of Edom along the east, and was to the south of the land of Israel.

Moses hinted this in the Torah (Deut. 2: 29), “As was done to me by the children of Esau who dwell in Seir (Edom) and by the Moabites who dwell in Ar,” implying that just as Edom did not let them pass, similarly Moab did not let them pass.

text.title: And they went through the wilderness:

pasuk.text: From west to east along the southern border of Edom and Moab.

text.title: and went around the land of Edom:

pasuk.text: Its entire southern border.
The entire southern border, and when they reached the southeastern corner they turned north to compass the eastern border.

text.title: and they came to the east of the land of Moab, and they encamped on the other side of the Arnon:

pasuk.text: To the end of the eastern border of the land of Moab whence began the land of Sichon and Og. They then conquered the side of the Jordan to the east of the land of Canaan (as the following verses indicate), and then crossed the Jordan, entering the land of Canaan from the east.

text.title: And they possessed… from the Arnon up to the Jabbok:

pasuk.text: That which you say was yours, (in reality) they (i.e., our forefathers) took it from Sichon.

text.title: and from the wilderness up to the Jordan:

pasuk.text: There were deserts situated east of the Jordan.

(Lit., on the hands of Arnon) I.e., along Arnon. These cities were from Moab, but they realized that they could not instigate war over them because Israel had conquered them from Sichon who had taken them from the king of Moab.

Since the land was conquered in the days of Joshua until Jephthah. From here we can derive if the periods of the judges that were mentioned up to this point include the years of oppression by the heathens or not. We have learned in Seder Olam (Ch. 12): Joshua led Israel twenty eight years, but I have no Scripture whence to derive it. Othniel led them forty years including the years of oppression by Cushan- rishathaim (above 3:11); after him was Ehud for eighty years (above 3:30) including the eighteen years of oppression by Eglon. This totals one hundred forty eight years. Deborah led them forty years (above 5:31) including the years of oppression by Jabin. This totals one hundred eighty eight years; afterwards were the seven years of oppression by Midian (above 6:1) and the forty years of Gideon (above 8: 28), then the three of Abimelech (above 9:22), thus totaling two hundred thirty eight years. Afterwards were the twenty three of Tola, and the twenty two of Jair (above 10:2,3), however one same year coincides for both of them; finally, adding the eighteen of Ammon prior to Jephthah’s introduction (above 10:8), this amounts to the three hundred years.
(Lit., he passed the children of Ammon) I.e., he passed over to the children of Ammon.
The plain of vineyards [after Targum Jonathan].
This is expressed in feminine form (the “tav” being vocalized with a חִירִיק) as in, (Song of Songs 4:9) לִבַּבְתִּנִי אֲחֹתִי כַלָּה (“You drew my heart, my sister, my beloved”).

text.title: (you) have become one of those that trouble me:

pasuk.text: All my blood is troubled. You have ruined my equilibrium (lit., feet thus causing me to fall).
Heb. וְיָרַדְתִּי

This is an expression of lamenting, as in (Isa. 15:3) “Upon her roofs and streets they all lament, lamenting with a cry יוֹרֵד בַּבֶּכִי)),” as one who is immersed in mourning until his body is broken (since יְרִידָה is also an expression of “breaking,” as in Lamen. 1:13). In an Aggadic interpretation Rabbi Tanchuma (Behukosai) explains “Upon the mountains” as referring to (her) presenting the case before the Sanhedrin (Great Court); perhaps they can find an opening to your (i.e., Jephthah’s) vow.

text.title: and she cried over her virginity:

pasuk.text: Heb. בְּתוּלֶיהָ. Since it does not say “over her maidens” (בְּתוּלוֹתֶיהָ) , it implies that this refers to her actual virginity.

They decreed that no one should do this anymore (i.e., they publicized that no one should offer a human being), because had Jephthah gone to Phinehas or vice versa, he would have nullified his (i.e., Jephthah’s) vow (i.e., he would have instructed him what the law is in such an instance). However, they were particular about their honor, and as a result she was destroyed. Consequently, they were punished; Phinehas, by the Divine presence leaving him as it is stated in (I) Chron. (9:20) “Previously God was with him,” so we see subsequently God was not with him; and Jephthah was afflicted with boils and dismemberment as it is stated, (below 12:7) “And he was buried in the cities [pl.] of Gilead.” (His limbs were buried in the various cities.) We can also interpret “And it was a statute in Israel” as connected to the following verse.
This they (i.e., the daughters of Israel) accepted upon themselves as a statute. לְתַנּוֹת To lament.
They crossed the Jordan (eastward) and went up north to Gilead.

text.title: because the lowest of Ephraim said, (Of what importance are) you Gileadites:

pasuk.text: The lowly of Ephraim belittled Gilead by saying to them, “Of what importance are you Gilead among Ephraim and Menasseh.” So renders Targum Jonathan .

text.title: And the Gileadites seized the fords…:

pasuk.text: They established guards at the fords.
(say) this stream (שִׁבֹּלֶת) of the river will I cross.

text.title: and he was not prepared to pronounce it properly:

pasuk.text: They stumbled in their speech.
This was Boaz (who came from Beth-lehem).
יַיִן וְשֵׁכָר. New and old wine [after Targum Jonathan].
(Lit., a thrower.) This is a razor because it casts and throws off hair.

text.title: and do not eat any unclean (things):

pasuk.text: Of those things that are prohibited to a Nazir.
To the lad that will be born.
after her counsel.

text.title: what shall be the rule for the lad, and his doing:

pasuk.text: What is proper for the lad and what shall be done to him [after Targum Jonathan].

text.title: Let us take you in now:

pasuk.text: Let us ingather you into the house.

text.title: that when your word will come:

pasuk.text: If a message will come from you, by knowing and recognizing your name we will honor you and do that which you request.
I.e., hidden. It is constantly changed and it is not known to what it was changed today.
(Lit., and at a time) I.e., and at this time.

text.title: He would not let us hear (such things) as these:

pasuk.text: He would not let us hear such news (of our child) if we were deserving of death.
To come within him at times (לִפְעָמִים).
I.e., a pretense to antagonize them.

text.title: and he talked to the woman (lit.):

pasuk.text: I.e., concerning the woman, he spoke to her relatives. So renders Targum Jonathan .
(Targum Jonathan renders) דְּדַבַּרְיָתָא קִינָא, a swarm of bees.

This is an expression of separating anything which is clinging, as by bread clinging to an oven, its removal is called רְדִיָּה (Sab. 117b) “One who separates (הָרוֹדֶה) bread from an oven,” (ibid. 95a) “One who separates (הָרוֹדֶה) from his hive,” since the honey is contained in honeycombs clinging to the walls of the vessel on all sides from wall to wall according to the circumference of the vessel. Likewise Targum Jonathan renders וַיִּרְדֵּהוּ as וְנַסְחֵיהּ (and he separated).

text.title: Now his father went down to the woman (lit.):

pasuk.text: I.e., concerning the woman [after Targum Jonathan].
companions.

text.title: And it was, on the seventh day:

pasuk.text: Of the week, not the seventh (day) of the feasting but rather the fourth day of feasting. קְרָאתֶם לָנוּ הֲלֹא הַלְיָרְשֵׁנוּ Targum Jonathan renders: Have you called us here (הֲלֹא = הֲלוֹם) to impoverish us?
I.e., the remainder of the seven days, from the fourth and onward.
Before sunset, since they still had time until evening.
This is allegorical (as Targum Jonathan renders): “Had you not interrogated my wife.”
A spirit of might emanating from God (Targum Jonathan). חֲלִיצוֹתָם I. e., the clothing that he removed (שֶחָלַץ has similar construction) from them.
She was given to one of his companions.

text.title: This time I shall be blameless:

pasuk.text: Justly will I harm them.

The tails, tail to tail. וַיִּפֶן implies he himself turned. וַיַּפֶן implies he made others turn. And likewise is conjugated every word whose verb contains a “heh” (at the end which drops such as גלה רבה פנה) as in, (Ex. 1:20) הָעָם וַיִּרֶב (“And the people multiplied”), (Lamen. 2:5) יְהוּדָה וַיֶרֶב בְּבַת (“And He multiplied in Judah grief”), (II Kings 25:21) וַיִּגֶל יְהוּדָה מֵעַל אַדְמָתוֹ (“And Judah exited from his land”), (II Kings 17:6) וַיֶּגֶל אֶת ישְׂרָאֵל אַשּׁוּרָה (“And he exiled Israel to Ashur”) [as per Shem Ephraim].
The son-in-law of the Philistine who is in Timnah.

text.title: Are you accustomed to do like this:

pasuk.text: Perhaps you are accustomed to do such; to give the wife of one to another?

(Lit., leg on thigh) (Targum Jonathan renders) “riders and foot soldiers.” A horse rider is not supported by his thigh but rather by his leg, with one foot inserted into the metal (stirrup) which hangs from the saddle. בִּסְעִיף In the cleft (which is a crevice between the protrusions) of the rock of Etam, and similarly, (Isa. 2:21) וּבִסְעִיפֵי הַסְּלָעִים (“The protrusions of the rocks”), (Isa. 10: 33) מְסָעֵף פֻּארָה (“Will cut down its branches”).
(lit., a jaw) This is the name of a place.

text.title: Why have you come up against us:

pasuk.text: Are we not subservient to you?
I.e., so that you should bind him and deliver him to us.

text.title: No, however we will bind you:

pasuk.text: I.e., We will not kill you, however, we will bind you.
A spirit of might emanating from God [quoting Targum Jonathan]. אֲסוּרָיו His bonds.
Moist. I saw in a book of cures that the moisture which issues from a wound is called טְרִיָּה.
With the jawbone of a donkey I piled many piles, i.e., with the jawbone of a donkey I heaped them up [after Targum Jonathan].

The socket within which the tooth rests, thich is shaped like a mortar (מַכְתֶּשֶׁת). עֵין הַקּוֹרֵא The fountain (מַעְיָן) that came about through the prayers of the one who called (הַקּוֹרֵא) to God.
To the people of Gaza it was told.
They conducted themselves quietly.
And he uprooted them from their place.
I.e., thin cords.

text.title: and his strength was not known:

pasuk.text: He did not have to exert himself to tear them.
I.e., thick cords.
Locks. Pelous(פלודיש) in O.F.
The wood upon which the weaver spreads out the warp. The name of this wood is ensouple in O.F. The roller (is called) ourdissuire in O.F.
And she pressed him.

text.title: And Delilah saw that he had told her:

pasuk.text: The words of truth are discernable.

text.title: and she called to the man:

pasuk.text: To the messenger of the lords.

text.title: And they brought him down to Gaza:

pasuk.text: (This was) the location of his first corruption (above v. 1).
With a mill. This was hard labor. However, our Sages explained that which they explained.
Upon which the building was supported.
Heb. וַהֲמִישֵנִי, Palpare (פלפאר) in O.F. as in, (Gen. 27: 12) “Perhaps my father will feel me” (יְמֻשֵּׁנִי).
Remember the twenty years that I judged Israel and did not tell one of them “Move this stick for me from one place to another.”

text.title: the vengeance for one of my two eyes:

pasuk.text: And the reward for the second eye reserve for me for the world to come, but here pay me the reward for one of them.
And he grasped. Embrasser (אינברצא) in O.F. as in, (Ruth 3: 8) “And the man trembled and was grasped” (וַיִּלָּפֵת), he was grasped by the arms of the woman.

text.title: Now there was a man from the mountain of Ephraim:

pasuk.text: Although the following two episodes are written at the end of this book; the one of Micah and the other about the concubine of Gibeah, they, nevertheless, occurred at the beginning of the period of the Judges. This was during the days of Othniel the son of Kenaz (and Cushan, above 3:8 11) as it says, (below 18:31) “And they accepted for themselves the graven image of Micah which he had made, throughout the period that the house of God was in Shiloh,” so we can derive that for the duration of Shiloh (Fourteen years after Israel’s crossing the Jordan, the Tabernacle was erected in Shiloh and remained there for three hundred sixty-nine years.) the image of Micah remained. Also, by the concubine of Gibeah it is said concerning the Jebusites of Jerusalem, (below 19:12) “We will not turn into (this) city of heathens,” so we can derive that they had not yet captured Jerusalem (which was captured by Judah, see above 1:8).
Heb. לָ. (Lit.) I.e., that was stolen from you (מִמּ). There is a similar verse: (I Sam. 21:6) “But women are withheld from us” (לָנוּ as מִמֶּנּוּ).
Anyone who stole it, and you also said the curse in my ears.
I admit that it is in my possession because I took it.

text.title: And he restored the eleven hundred pieces of silver to his mother:

pasuk.text: He said he would return them to her, and wherever they were they would be in her domain.

text.title: I have dedicated the silver (before the Lord) from my hand for my son:

pasuk.text: I accepted upon myself to transfer them from my possession to your possession for the purpose of a form and a molten image. Give them to me now, and then, from (being in) my possession I will return them to you. Some say that this woman was Delilah because it mentions eleven hundred pieces of silver (as above 16:5), but they are mistaken because Micah preceded Samson many years. However, these sections are adjacent because of the wicked silver which was an equal amount in both of them, and by their both being silver of misfortune.
Heb. אֱלֹהִים. And so (is rendered) each אֱלֹהִים stated in this section as being profane with the exception of, (below 18:31) “Throughout the period that the house of God was in Shiloh.”

text.title: and he initiated (lit., and he filled the hand of) one:

pasuk.text: I.e., he indoctrinated him in the service of the image to be a priest to it. Any initiation whereby a person enters onto a higher level is called (מִלּוּי יָדַיִם) “filling the hands.” Revetir in O.F., and when office is bestowed upon a person it is called Reveture in O.F.

And he was a Levite from his mother’s side. However, our Sages said (B.B. 109b) that since he committed deeds like those of Menasseh (i.e., he committed idolatry) who came from Judah he is called “Of the family of Judah,” but he was really a Levite the son of Gershom the son of our teacher Moses, as is stated below, (18:30) “And Jonathan the son of Gershom…”
I.e., (while continuing) the way he was travelling.
To earn my livlihood.
(Lit., for the days) I.e., at the end of the year.
A pair of garments that is suited for all people according to their needs for a year. וְעֵרֶ בְּגָדִים - Appareillement in O.F. וּמִחְיָתֶ I.e., your sustenance.
(lit., went) after his advice.

text.title: for (until that day) there had not fallen to them:

pasuk.text: An inheritance befitting them in the previously conquered land, as it says, (Joshua 19:47) “And the border of the children of Dan went out from them.” From here we can also derive that this occurred at the immediate beginning of the Judges’ period.

There are many questions here. Are you not of the descendants of Moses our teacher of whom it is said: (Ex. 3:5) “Do not draw near here;” (ibid. 4:11) “Who gave speech (פֶּה same letters as פֹּה) to a person;” and (ibid 4:2) “What is this in your hand?”
(translation follows Targum Jonathan . Rashi, however, explains:) Of the teraphim that speak through magic.

text.title: before the Lord is your way in which you shall go:

pasuk.text: (Lit.) Before the Holy One, blessed be He, it is revealed, however, this one is worthless.

text.title: for there was none in the land to put them to shame for any thing:

pasuk.text: Not one of them ever needs his friend’s assistance that he should have the opportunity to send him back empty-handed and embarass him, as it says, (v. 10) “Where there is nothing lacking.” So I have heard. יוֹרֵשׁ עֶצֶר There are few heirs, consequently, if these are killed there will not remain any other opposition to battle with the occupants of the portion.
From the assistance of the Zidonians.

text.title: and had no bond (lit., word) with any man:

pasuk.text: (They do not have) any treaty contracted that anyone should come to their aid when necessary.
(Lit.) Meaning, What do you have to respond? What did you find on the territory of our lot? What about the people, are they strong or weak?
You are slothful.
The burdens. (This refers to) any thing which has difficulty in moving, not being able to run if pursued by people. Pezantume in O.F.
I.e., the children of Dan to those that called them.
what remains to me?
The tempermental ones of our group.

This was the name of the city. In the book of Joshua (19:47) it is called Leshem because they found there a precious stone named Leshem (turquoise) which was used on the breastplate (of the High Priest see Ex. 28:19) representing the tribe of Dan. His (i.e., Dan’s) name was written on (the) Leshem, thereby verifying that this was their rightful portion.
Out of respect for Moses (משֶׁה) a “nun” was inserted thereby changing the name (מְנַשֶּׁה). This letter was written suspended to indicate that it was not Menasseh but actually Moses.

text.title: until the day of the exile of the land:

pasuk.text: In the days of Sancherib, during the first exile.

text.title: And his concubine turned away from him:

pasuk.text: She turned from his house to the outside. Every expression of זְנוּת implies going out (rendered (נפקת ברא, e.g., departing from her husband to love others.
Overnight.
I.e., the sun (has weakened) from its might and has declined to set.

text.title: it is the resting (part) of the day:

pasuk.text: It is the time that all wayfarers turn to rest indoors.

text.title: but we will journey up to Gibeah:

pasuk.text: Of Benjamin.
Heb. וְלַנּוּ. To be understood as וְלַנְנוּ, since the “dagesh” of the “nun” replaces the appropriate second “nun”.

text.title: and (I am going) to the House of the Lord:

pasuk.text: I am going to Shiloh (which was in Ephraim).

text.title: and gave fodder to the donkeys:

pasuk.text: And he gave food (יְבוּל) to the donkeys. וַיָּבָל is aprovender in O.F.

text.title: so that we may be intimate with him (lit., know him):

pasuk.text: Homosexually.
Because she was dead.
The chiefs of the people.
They intended to kill. Adesmernt in O.F.

text.title: that they may do when they come:

pasuk.text: I.e., when they come at this time to Gibeah of Benjamin, according to all the disgrace, etc.
Agreeing to the same plan.

text.title: throughout all the tribes of Benjamin:

pasuk.text: His ten families were reckoned as ten tribes, so that from Rachel would (also) issue twelve tribes (two coming from Joseph).
Their right hands were shriveled. They had no use of it, as though it was closed, as in, (Psalms 69:16) “Do not close (תֶּאְטַר) upon me, O well, your mouth.”
I.e., these seven hundred men.
At a thread of a hair breadth. וְלֹא יַחֲטִיא And not miss.

But they did not attempt to ask whether they would be the victor or the vanquished. However, eventually when they did ask, God said, (v. 28) “Go up, for tomorrow I will deliver them into your hand.” Then they (i.e., the Urim and Tummim) agreed (הִסְכִּימוּ) and fulfilled their words.
They were punished because they were not equally zealous about the incident of the image of Micah which had already occurred.
In the plains of Jericho [quoting Targum Jonathan]. מֵגִיחַ Drew forth, as in, (Job 40: 23) “Draw (יָגִיחַ) the Jordan to his mouth,” and, (Psalms 22: 10)"You draw (גֹחִי) me from the womb.

Heb. מַעֲרֵה גָבַע From a narrow place, the naked (עֶרְוָתָהּ) exposed part of Gibeah of Benjamin, i.e., the bare part from where it is easily conquered, as in, (Gen. 42:9) “To see the nakedness (עֶרְוַת) of the land have you come.”

text.title: and the men of Israel gave (place):

pasuk.text: Those that were in the field (v. 31) gave a place for Benjamin to flee towards Gibeah, because Israel relied on the liers-in-wait to go out towards them (in battle).
With a horn. Another interpretation is: They drew with the horn the people that were with them into the city.

text.title: Now there was an appointed time:

pasuk.text: Initially there was a signal (prepared) between Israel and the liers-in-wait, that the liers-in-wait should raise a great deal of smoke from the city so that Israel should realize that they had conquered Gibeah. מַשְׂאַת הֶעָשָׁן A pillar of smoke (which rises נָשָׂא).

text.title: Now as the men of Israel turned:

pasuk.text: Now Scripture returns to the beginning of the episode and repeats to explain about the twenty-five thousand written above (v. 35), how they fell and where they fell.
The liers-in-wait that entered the city destroyed them within the tribe within the city (sic).

Like a crown (כֶּתֶר) that encircles the head, and similarly, (Psalms 22:13) “The strong bulls of Bashan encircled me (כִּתְּרוּנִי) ,” and also in (Hab. 1:4) “Because the wicked encircles (מַכְתִּיר) the righteous.” The expression עֲטָרָה (Lit., crown) is also used to denote encircling, as in, (I Sam. 23:26) “And Saul and his men were encircling (עוֹטְרִים David and his men to capture them.” הִרְדִיפֻהוּ They called upon them a chase, shouting one to another to pursue.

text.title: (near their) resting places they overtook them:

pasuk.text: Near the cities wherein they rest, there they overtook them. הִדְרִיכֻהוּ I.e., they overtook them, and there is a similar expression in the Talmud, (Kethubos 60b) “He ran after him a parasang in the sand but did not overtake him” (אדרכיה).
Eastward of Gibeah (as the verse concludes).

text.title: And there fell of Benjamin eighteen thousand men:

pasuk.text: In the field (cf. v. 31) during the battle.
Deathblow after deathblow, just as one gleans after the harvest.
This leads to a sum of twenty- three thousand men.
This is the name of a place.

text.title: and killed of them two thousand men:

pasuk.text: This amounts to the twenty-five thousand stated above (v. 35). Concerning the additional hundred written above, it was not explained where they fell.

text.title: turned upon the children of Benjamin:

pasuk.text: That were in all the cities.

They destroyed all the inhabitants of the cities, even the cattle, thus people are included in “destroying” since “ מְתֹם” is an expression of destruction. There is a difficulty concerning the whereabouts of a thousand since twenty-six thousand were numbered from the cities and from Gibeah seven (text amended) hundred (v. 15). However, here the count of the fallen is twenty-five thousand and one hundred (v. 35) plus the six hundred that escaped to the rock of Rimmon. But perhaps (amended) the (undermined) thousand fled to the cities and fell the following day when the children of Israel returned to the Benjamite cities to destroy the women and children (as is stated in this verse).
That there should be missing.
They repented to plan for them a program of survival.
They placed them over the openings of barrels of wine. The non- virgin would allow a fragrance to pass whereas the virgin would not allow a fragrance to pass.
(This) was not sufficient for them.

text.title: (There must be) an inheritance for the remnant:

pasuk.text: The territory of the tribe has remained empty. Propose a suggestion that the escaped remnant may beget children and occupy their portion so that there should not be blotted out a tribe from Israel.
On the east side of the highway. Shiloh is to the north of Beth-el and to the south of Lebonah and to the east of the highway that goes from Beth-el to Shechem.
to go against us in battle.

text.title: then we will say to them we took pity on them:

pasuk.text: We took pity on them because they do not know what to do, because we did not take for each man his wife in the war with Jabesh-gilead but only for four hundred of their men. And if you are concerned about your oath, (be assured that) you have no sin in this matter, because you did not give them your daughters (cf. above v. 1) that you should be guilty in this, (rather) peace will be with you, do not fear.
